browser.htmlContent:
• Remove physical barriers (ear buds), and orient yourself physically towards the person.
  • Don't interrupt or talk over the other person.

• Use your own preferences as a starting point. What helps you know someone is listening?
  • Use facial expressions, space/proximity, silence, varied eye contact, nodding, and other nonverbal communication.
  • Use verbal cues like "mmhmmm" or "I see what you mean"
  • Allow a pass after they finish speaking.

• Develop an awareness of how the student you work with listens.
  • Pay attention to how your own listening behavior is received - do they seem uncomfortable?
  • Learn about mirroring.
